newsitem.title: USA: Cuban exiles say CNN is the "Castro News Network".
newsitem.headline: Cuban exiles say CNN is the "Castro News Network".

text.p: Miami's Cuban exile community criticized CNN's debut broadcast from Cuba on Tuesday, saying it was impossible for the U.S. cable television network to present a balanced view from the Communist-ruled island.
Miami radio listeners quickly passed judgment, labelling CNN the "Castro News Network."
Telephone lines at Spanish-language stations were jammed by critical callers almost as soon as the broadcast began on Monday evening with a live report from Havana.
Cuban-Americans said Cable News Network might intend to provide balanced coverage of Cuban politics, but would inevitably be used by President Fidel Castro's government to support its agenda.

Ninoska Perez, host of a Spanish-language radio broadcast and a spokeswoman for the staunchly anti-Castro Cuban-American National Foundation, questioned why CNN had not put Cuban dissidents on the air during its initial broadcast.
The bureau opened by CNN correspondent Lucia Newman is the first permanent office of a U.S. media outlet in Cuba in 28 years.

"She showed yesterday a little kid with the typical communist propaganda ... but why didn't she mention that same kid gets a ration card ... they can only get milk up to (age) seven years? That's the kind of thing that would really reflect the kind of country that Cuba is," Perez said.
"It's too early to tell how accurate they are going to be ... If they are balanced, it is going to be great," said Jaime Suchliki, a professor of Latin American history at the University of Miami.
But, he added: "I also think the Cuban people should be allowed to see it."
For the U.S. government, allowing CNN to open a bureau in Cuba was not enough to establish a free flow of information.
"There is no press freedom at all," Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs Jeffrey Davidow said at an international press freedom conference in Panama City.

"The fact that Castro still intends to limit the number of foreign media and prevent international media from distributing information within Cuba itself is a testament to the Cuban government's fear of a free press," Davidow said on Monday after the CNN broadcast.

Cuba gave CNN, an Atlanta-based division of Time Warner Inc., permission to open a bureau in November. CNN is the first U.S. news organization with a permanent bureau on the Communist-ruled island since 1969.
The Clinton administration also granted permission to nine other U.S. news organizations to apply to operate in Cuba, but only CNN has been authorized by the Cuban government so far.
The other media are ABC, CBS, Univision, the Miami Herald, Dow Jones News Services, Cuba Info, the Chicago Tribune and the Sun-Sentinel of Fort Lauderdale, Florida.
Cuban news organizations are barred from having bureaux in the United States, which last year stiffened its long-standing economic embargo against Cuba.
Non-U.S. media have been allowed to operate in Cuba for many years, including Reuters, Agence-France Presse, Notimex, EFE, El Pais, the Financial Times of London and the British Broadcasting Corp.
